html:
Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈsa.li.oː/, [ˈsa.lʲi.oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈsa.li.o/, [ˈsaː.li.ɔ]

Etymology 1[edit]

From Proto-Indo-European *sel- (“to spring”). Cognates include Ancient Greek ἅλλομαι (hállomai) and Sanskrit सरति (sárati).

Verb[edit]

saliō (present infinitive salīre, perfect active saluī, supine saltum); fourth conjugation

  1. (intransitive) I leap, jump, bound
  2. (intransitive) I spring forth, flow down
  3. (transitive, of male animals) I mount for copulation
Usage notes[edit]
  • This verb is mostly intransitive and passive forms (from the meaning of "mounting") are mostly unattested.

  • dēsiliō

  • salientēs
  • salisātiō

Descendants[edit]
  • Aragonese: salir, sallir, salre
  • Aromanian: sar, ansar, sãriri
  • Asturian: salir
  • Catalan: sallir
  • Corsican: sede, seda, seie
  • English: sally, salient
  • Extremaduran: salil
  • Galician: saír, salir
  • Italian: salire
  • Leonese: salire
  • Mirandese: salir
  • Occitan: salir
  • Old French: salir, saillir
    • Middle French: saillir
      • French: saillir
  • Old Portuguese: sair
  • Portuguese: sair
  • Romanian: sări, sărire
  • Romansch: siglir, saglir, saglier
  • Sardinian: salire, saliri
  • Spanish: salir

Etymology 2[edit]

From sāl (“salt”).

Alternative forms[edit]

  • salliō
  • sallō
  • salō

Verb[edit]

saliō (present infinitive salīre, perfect active saliī, supine salītum); fourth conjugation

  1. I salt.
  2. I sprinkle before sacrifice.

  • salsē
  • salsus
Related terms[edit]
  • sāl
  • salīllum
  • salīnae
  • salīnārius
  • salīnātor
  • salīnum
  • salipotēns
  • salītūra
  • salītus
Descendants[edit]
  • Vulgar Latin: *salāre (“to salt”)
    • Catalan: salar
    • French: saler
    • Friulian: salâ
    • Italian: salare
    • Occitan: salar
    • Romanian: săra, sărare
    • Sicilian: salari
    • Spanish: salar
    • Venetian: salar, sałar
  • Vulgar Latin: *insalāre (“to salt”)
    • Aromanian: ãnsar, ãnsãrari
    • Italian: insalare
    • Romansch: ensalar, ansalar
  • Vulgar Latin: *salicāre
    • Galician: salgar
    • Portuguese: salgar
  • Vulgar Latin: salsus (“salted”)
    • Asturian: salsa (“saline water”)
    • Italian: salso
    • Portuguese: salsa (“parsley”)
    • Spanish: salso
  • Vulgar Latin: *salsa (“sauce”)
    • Asturian: salsa
    • Catalan: salsa
    • French: sauce (see there for further descendants)
    • Galician: salsa
    • Italian: salsa
    • Occitan: salsa
    • → Old Danish: salsæ
    • Spanish: salsa (see there for further descendants)
  • Sardinian: salire, saliri
  • Albanian: shëllij

References[edit]
